qas.question: What is an example of an organism that has a portion of its genetic material outside of its chromosomes?
What is an example of an organism whose full complement of genetic material resides in its chromosomes?
Where is additional genetic material found in pathogenic microbes?

plausible_answers.text: additional genetic material besides that which resides in their chromosomes

qas.question: What do viruses always carry within their structure?
Where is additional genetic material found in a virus?
What is another word used for genome?
What organism has part of its genetic material inside a virus?
What do most viruses more complex than plasmids carry?

context: Most biological entities that are more complex than a <a1_0>virus<a1_0/> sometimes or always carry <b3_0><b7_0>additional genetic material<b7_0/> besides that which resides in their chromosomes<b3_0/>. In some contexts, such as sequencing the genome of a <a0_0><b6_0>pathogenic microbe<b6_0/><a0_0/>, "genome" is meant to include information stored on this auxiliary material, which is carried in <a2_0><b4_0><b5_0>plasmids<b5_0/><b4_0/><a2_0/>. In such circumstances then, "genome" describes all of the genes and information on non-coding DNA that have the potential to be present.
